StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: In treated water from 30 Canadian water treatment facilities in which 2-/3-xylene combined were measured, 27% and 20% were positive in summer and winter, respectively, with maximum values of 7 and 2 ppb, respectively(1). In the raw water of these same facilities, 7% and 17% of the plants contained combined 2-/3-xylene in summer and winter, respectively with maximum levels being under 1 ppb(1). In drinking water samples drawn from the Great Lakes 12 municipalities tested on one or two days, 5 communities were free of 2-/3-xylene combined, with median community levels being 1.0 ppb and the highest sample of the combined isomers being 12 ppb(2). 2-Xylene was quantitatively detected in drinking water from Philadelphia, PA(3), Washington, DC(4), Tuscaloosa, AL(5), Houston, TX(5), Cincinnati, OH(6) and Seattle, WA(6). In 3 New Orleans treatment plants, the average concentration of water collected over 2 days was 3.4 ppb(7). Bank filtered drinking water in the Netherlands contained a maximum of 30 parts per trillion 2-xylene(8). Five drinking water wells near and down gradient from a landfill contained 0.2-1.5 ppb 2-xylene, a control well upstream contained 0.8 ppb(9). In a survey of organics in drinking water derived from groundwater sources, 2-/4-xylene combined were found in 2.1% of 280 sample sites supplying <10,000 persons and 1.1% of 186 sites supplying >10,000 persons. The maximum combined concentrations were 0.59 and 0.91 ppb, respectively(10). 2-Xylene was detected in all 14 drinking water supplies studies, 10 from surface sources and 4 from ground sources in the lowland of Great Britain(11). 2-Xylene was detected in all tap water samples produced offshore in September/October 1990 at seven platform sites in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea, at concentrations ranging from 41 ng/L to 4040 ng/L(12). Drinking water collected from 1205 domestic wells between 1985-2002 had positive 2-xylene detections in 8 samples(13).

Reference: (1) Dowty BJ et al; Environ Sci Technol 9: 762-5 (1975)
(2) Bertsch W et al; J Chromatogr 112: 701-18 (1975)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: 2-Xylene was detected, not quantified, in the Mississippi River(1), the Black Warrior River in Tuscaloosa, AL(2), the River Glatt in Switzerland(3), and the Besos and Llobregat Rivers in Spain(4). Raw water samples collected at 14 sampling locations in May and October 1989, from the Adige River, Italy, had an average 2-xylene concentration of 0.17 ppb, (range of <0.005 to 0.37 ppb), and 0.62 ppb (range of 0.027 to 4.79 ppb), respectively(5). 2-Xylene was detected, 110 ng/L, in Sava river water near Zagreb, Northern Croatia, Yugoslavia(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEAWATER: 2-Xylene concentration in samples from Vineyard Sound, MA samples taken from March through June ranged from 1.8 to 25 parts per trillion and averaged 9.4 parts per trillion(1). Open ocean and coastal sections of the Gulf of Mexico contained 1-30 parts per trillion 2-xylene(2). 2-Xylene was detected in surface waters of the sea collected near Portugal(3). A uniform pattern of alkylated benzenes was found in the Baltic Sea and central Atlantic(3). 2-Xylene was detected at a concentration of 1.5 ppm in surface waters (depth of 10 m), sampled at a 36 station grid site covering approximately 23,000 square kilometers near the Puerto Rico deepwater industrial waste dump site(4). The Tees estuary in the United Kingdom (mid-estuary) contained 2-xylene at a concentration of 1,340 ng/L(5). 2-Xylene was detected, not quantified iIn near surface and near bottom samples collected from Narrangansett Bay, RI(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW: The concentration of 2-xylene in rain in Portugal ranged from 12-110 parts per trillion, with a mean concentration of 45 parts per trillion(1). The concentration of 2-xylene detected in winter snow, winter rain, spring rain, summer rain, and autumn rain from Dubendorf, Switzerland in 1985 were 530, 150, 23, 20, and 76 ng/L, respectively(2). The average concentration of 2-xylene was 0.45 ng/mL (range 0 to 2.6 ng/mL) in cloud water collected at Gibbs Peak in Mt Mitchell State Park (2006 m MSL), NC, on several days between May and October 1987 and May and July 1988(3). 2-Xylene was detected in surface Antarctic snow in seven out of eight samples, taken during 1987-88, 1988-89, and 1990-91, at concentrations ranging from 5 ng/L (detection limit) to 80 ng/L; 2-xylene was detected in deep snow samples (1 m and 2 m below the surface), taken in 1990-91, at concentrations of 12 to 13 ng/L 1 m below the surface, and 7 to 11 ng/L 2 m below the surface(4). Snow and ice samples collected directly in cloud in 2005 and 2006 at Jungfraujoch, Germany contained mean 2-xylene levels ranging from 79-380 ng/L(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: In a comprehensive survey of wastewater from 4000 industrial and publicly owned treatment works (POTWs) sponsored by the Effluent Guidelines Division of the US EPA, 2-xylene was identified in discharges of the following industrial categories (positive occurrences; median concn in ppb, to two significant figures): timber products (98; 170), iron and steel manufacturing (4; 17), petroleum refining (11; 61), nonferrous metals (3; 0.9), paving and roofing (2; 33), paint and ink (39; 150), printing and publishing (2; 310), coal mining (11; 26), organics and plastics (13; 11), inorganic chemicals (7; 1100), textile mills (2; 120), plastics and synthetics (8; 120), pulp and paper (1; 56), rubber processing (4; 9.4), soaps and detergents (1; 130), auto and other laundries(8; 200), pesticides manufacture (2; 130), pharmaceuticals (6; 94), porcelain/enameling (2; 28), electronics (7; 60), oil and gas extraction (6; 23), organic chemicals (4; 290), mechanical products (7; 380), transportation equipment (2; 25), amusements and athletic goods (2; 1000), and publicly owned treatment works (45; 39)(1). Maximum effluents above 5000 ppb were observed in the following industrial categories (maximum effluent in ppb, to two significant figures): timber products (6200), petroleum refining (5900), paint and ink (7600), organics and plastics (6700), and mechanical products (11000)(3). 2-Xylene was detected in the headspace emissions of 5 out of 26 gel type air fresheners purchased in South Korea(2). The concentration of 2-xylene measured in the gas phase emissions from burning pine wood was 18.1 mg/kg wood burned(1). 2-Xylene emission factors of 0.96-26.7 mg/kg fuel burned were determined using woodstove/fireplace burning of Eurpoean beach, Pyrenean oak and black poplar wood(4). 2-Xylene (plus styrene) was detected in the volatiles emitted from corn, alfalfa and cereal silage at concentrations of 0.05-0.20 ng/L(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: Emission rates of 2-xylene measured for 10 diesel fuels ranged from 0.29-2.56 mg/bhp-hr for engines without an after treatment device and from below detection to 0.48 mg/bhp-hr (brake horsepower) for diesel engines with an after treatment device(1). Concentrations of 2-xylene were 5,410 and 562,000 ug/km in catalyst-equipped and noncatalyst-equipped gasoline-powered motor vehicle tailpipe emissions, respectively(2). The concentration of this substance measured in gasoline was 19,700 ug/g(2). 2-Xylene was detected in 73 out of 249 samples with a median and maximum concentrations of 0.08 and 2.37 ug/L, respectively(3). The mean concentration of 2-xylene measured in 24 unleaded gasoline samples was 2.2% by weight(3). Aqueous emissions of xylenes from a two stroke and a four stroke gasoline outboard engine ranged from 0.27-0.86 and 0.06-0.09 g/kW-hr, respectively(4). The average combined exhaust emissions of 2-xylene/C9 paraffins from a 1975 to 1985 model year test fleet were 1.8% and 1.4% of total hydrocarbon emissions at normal urban and normal high speed driving(5). Evaporative hydrocarbon emissions contained 1.3% 2-xylene/C9 paraffins(5). In a transportation-related source profile of volatile hydrocarbons in Atlanta, 1990, 2-xylene was detected in the following (ppbC % of total nonmethane organic compounds): motor-vehicle emissions (roadway), 1.7; airport emissions, 1.2; aircraft emissions, 0.65(6). 2-Xylene was also detected in different octane grades of gasoline from six major vendors in Atlanta, 1990, as follows (ppbC % of total nonmethane organic compounds): whole gas weighted average of all octanes, 2.6; whole gas 87 octane, 2.3; whole gas 89 octane, 2.6; headspace gas (24 °C) weighted average of all octanes, 0.12; headspace gas (32 °C) weighted average of all octanes, 0.21(6). Numerous other studies have identified 2-xylene in motor-vehicle and roadway emissions(7-12).

StringWithMarkup.String: 2-Xylene has been detected in the ambient air of municipal landfills and hazardous waste sites in NJ(1,2). Landfill gas from several landfill methane recovery sites contained 2-xylene at the following concentrations (average concentration, ppm vol): inlet gas, 1.3; product gas, 0.4; surface gas, 0.1; moderately processed landfill gas, 1.3; highly processed landfill gas, 0.1(3). 2-Xylene was detected in leachate from hazardous waste landfills, 10 to 1900 ppb, and sanitary landfills, 4.2 to 38 ppb(4). 2-Xylene was detected in leachate and storm water runoff from a municipal landfill in Orlando, FL(5). Gas samples from wells of 3 old and 1 active municipal landfill contained 2-xylene (average concentration ranged from 0.6 mg/cu m to 35 mg/cu m)(6). 2-Xylene was detected in UK digested sewage sludges from 12 sewage treatment works(7).

StringWithMarkup.String: 2-Xylene was detected in aqueous energy-related effluents at the following concentrations: product water sample in situ coal gasification (Hanna, WY), 472 ppb; aqueous sample from dewatering well prior to in situ coal gasification (Gillette, WY), 6.5 ppb; process water from in situ coal gasification (Gillette, WY), 82 ppb; aqueous condensate from low-Btu gasification of Rosebud coal (Morgantown, WV), 181 ppb; retort water from in situ oil shale processing (Rock Springs, WY), 6 ppb(1). 2-Xylene was quantified as 0.82 wt% of petroleum refinery emissions taken at ground level, one mile downwind of a major refinery in Romeoville, IL(2). StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: The reported mean concentration of 2-xylene measured in the outdoor air at 36 homes in New York City during the TEACH study was 2.00 ug/cu m in the summer and 1.52 ug/cu m in the winter(1). Geometric mean concentrations of 2-xylene measured in the atmosphere of S. Mario Capua Vetere in Southern Italy were reported to be 4.7 ug/cu m during working days and 3.1 ug/cu m on weekends(5). Reported concentrations of 2-xylene measured in Rome, Italy were 106 ug/cu m in a traffic tunnel, 42 ug/uc m above a heavy-traffic road, and 2.4 ug/cu m at a park located away from the city center(6). StringWithMarkup.String: 2-Xylene has been identified as a volatile component of baked potatoes(1), fried bacon(2), dried legumes(3), fried chicken(4), roasted filberts(5), raw beef(6), scrambled eggs(7), and floured chickpea seeds(8). 2-Xylene was identified as a volatile component of water-boiled duck meat, 1.9 ppb; duck fat, 15 ppb; Cantonese style roasted duck, 1.9 ppb; and Cantonese style roasted duck gravy, 10 ppb(9). 2-Xylene was detected as a volatile component of salt-fermented fish pastes including (mean concentration in ng/g): anchovy, 130; big-eyed herring, 100; and shrimp, 59(10). 2-Xylene was identified as a volatile organic compound in 32 out of 234 table-ready food items, concentrations ranging from 3.7 to 24 ppb, cake doughnuts contained the highest level of 2-xylene of those food items surveyed(11). 2-Xylene was identified as a component in the aroma concentrates of cured beef(12). 2-Xylene has been identified in the volatile portion of chicken, beef, and pork(13).

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the 2012 TSCA Inventory Update Reporting data, 8 reporting facilities estimate the number of persons reasonably likely to be exposed during the manufacturing, processing, or use of 2-xylene (benzene, 1,2-dimethyl-) in the United States may be as low as <10 workers and as high as 1000-9999 workers per plant; the data may be greatly underestimated due to confidential business information (CBI) or unknown values(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 25,994 workers (5,812 of these were female) were potentially exposed to 2-xylene in the US(1). Occupational exposure to 2-xylene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where 2-xylene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to 2-xylene via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing 2-xylene(SRC). Contact with xylene occurs from a variety of consumer products, including gasoline, paint, varnish, shellac, rust preventives, and cigarette smoke(2).

Reference: (1) Angerer J, Wulf H; Int Arch Occup Environ Health 56: 307-21 (1985)
(2) Eitzer BD; Environ Sci Technil 29: 896-902 (1995)
(3) Kawai T et al; Int Arch Occup Environ Health 63: 69-75 (1991)

(6) Wadden RA et al; Am Ind Hyg Assoc J 56: 368-76 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: 35 varnish spray men, who were varnishing vehicles, were exposed to 2-xylene at an average concentration of 2.1 ppm in personal air(1). 3-, 2-Xylene (combined isomers) were detected in the workplace air of a solid waste composting facility at a maximum observed concentration of 15000 ug/cu m(2). 121 male workers in a vehicle metal parts plant, engaged in dip-coating metal parts with rust resistant paint, were exposed to a mean geometric vapor concentration of 2-xylene of 0.8 ppm(3). In the petroleum industry, outside operators, transport drivers, and service attendants were exposed to mean levels of 2-xylene of 0.11, 0.20, and 0.091 mg/cu m, respectively(4). Workers in small screen printing plants were exposed to 2-xylene via indoor air at maximum concentrations ranging from 0.06-3.26 mg/cu m(5). In a sheet-fed offset printing shop, the 2-xylene average concentration in air ranged from 0.41 mg/cu m in the air supply to 0.85 mg/cu m over a specific line(6).

Reference: (1) Wallace LA et al; Environ Res 43: 290-307 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: As part of the EPA's Total Exposure Assessment Methodology (TEAM) study, the concn of various toxic substances in the personal air (2 consecutive 12-hour periods) of sample populations was measured as well as the outdoor air near the residences(1). The weighted median results for 2-xylene in personal air in Bayonne and Elizabeth, NJ, an industrial/chemical manufacturing area, were 5.4, 5.2, and 8.0 ug/cu m in the fall 1981, summer 1982, and winter 1983(1). The corresponding results for outdoor air were 3.0, 3.6, and 3.4 ug/cu m(1). For comparison, the personal air of a sample of residents of a manufacturing city without a chemical or petroleum refining industry, Greensboro, NC, and a small rural, agricultural town in North Dakota contained 3.6 and 2.7 ug/cu m, respectively of 2-xylene, and the outdoor air 0.6 ug/cu m and not detectable, respectively(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: The mean concentration of 2-xylene was 0.05 ng/mL in the blood of 134 school-age children that participated in the School Health Initiative: Environment, Learning, Disease (SHIELD) study in Minneapolis, MN(1). The mean concentration of 2-xylene was 0.06 ng/mL in the blood of 43 children living in an inner city neighborhood of Minneapolis, MN(2). In the USEPA's Total Exposure Methodology (TEAM) Study, 83% of the 358 breath samples of residents of Elizabeth and Bayonne, NJ tested contained measurable quantities of 2-xylene; median and maximum concentrations 2.2 and 220 ug/cu m, respectively(3). People recently exposed to potential sources of 2-xylene such as from paint, furniture refinishing, printing, science laboratories, plastics manufacturing, and chemical plants had significantly higher levels of 2-xylene in their breath(4). 2-Xylene was detected in the blood of 35 varnish spray men (masks worn) at an average level of 26.6 ug/L; its metabolites, o-methylhippuric acid, 73 ppm average; 2,3-dimethylphenol, 0.5 ppm average; and 3,4-dimethylphenol, 0.8 ppm average, were detected in the urine(4). Urine samples from 121 male workers in a vehicle metal parts plant, contained a mean concentration of 14.0 mg/l o-methylhippuric acid, a metabolite of 2-xylene(5). The mean blood concentration in a non-occupationally exposed US population was 0.14 ppb(6).

Reference: (1) Wallace L et al; Arch Environment Health 42: 272-9 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: Personal air monitors and breath samples were used to monitor o-xylene and other volatile compounds in the breath of 200 smokers and 322 nonsmokers in New Jersey and California during 12-hr sampling periods. The monitor measured only sidestream and exhaled mainstream smoke. Concentrations were also measured in a subsample of homes and outdoor air. Compared to nonsmokers, o-xylene was significantly higher in the breath of persons who had smoked tobacco the day they were monitored (p <0.001). Unweighed geometric mean breath concentrations for smokers in NJ (fall); NJ (summer); NJ (winter); Los Angeles, CA (winter); Los Angeles (spring); Antioch/Pittsburg, CA (spring) were 2.4, 1.2, 1.6, 1.5, 1.6, and 1.0 ug/cu m, respectively; values for nonsmokers were 1.9, 0.6, 1.0, 0.6, 0.4, and 0.3 ug/cu m, respectively. Values from personal air samplers were only occasionally significantly higher. Indoor air concentrations in homes with smokers were significantly higher in fall and winter. Median breath concentrations of nonsmokers exposed to tobacco smoke at work but not at home were significantly higher than those not exposed at work(1).

Reference: (1) Kinney PL et al; Environ Health Perspect (Suppl) 110: 539-46 (2002)
(2) Dodson RE et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 8498-505 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: The reported mean concentration of 2-xylene measured in the personal air of 36 high school students in New York City participating in the TEACH study was 3.93 ug/cu m in the summer and 2.24 ug/cu m in the winter(1). A median measured personal 2-xylene concentration of 1.5 ug/cu m was determined for participants of the BEAM study which included 55 individuals employed in nonmanufacturing workplaces, including schools and offices, and living in suburban or urban locations in the greater Boston, MA area(2).

Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
